Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Engineer: University of Cincinnati (UC) Cyberinfrastructure Engineer and Educator (CI2E)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Cincinnati (UC) is establishing a Campus Cyberinfrastructure Engineer and Educator (CI2E) FTE. The CI2E works side by side with UC's researchers and students to facilitate the use and integration of local, regional and national cyberinfrastructure components with Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) research. The CI2E improves STEM education in the classroom and in the laboratory by providing relevant curriculum and guest lectures; opens new opportunities for research partnerships between universities and industry; and promotes commercialization and job growth. The CI2E helps the university fulfill the research pathways identified in the university's Third Century strategy, including research in engineering, climate change, clean water and sustainability, analytics, high-energy physics and medicine. The UC CI2E provides educational outreach opportunities to encourage women, first-generation college attendees and underserved populations to explore careers in sustainable networking and the future of big data.

The CC*DNI Campus CI2E FTE facilitates collaboration across the UCScienceNet, identifying opportunities and bottlenecks and recommending strategic upgrades to our existing campus cyberinfrastructure to create a highly functional and integrated whole. The CI2E works with researchers to utilize software defined networking (SDN) and OpenFlow resources to achieve optimization and the high-throughput capacity required to achieve UC's STEM education and research goals funded by the NSF, NASA, DOE, DoD, USEPA, USGS and private industry in many disciplines. S/he leads UC's ScienceDMZ, IPv6, BCP 38 and related network security efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-funded Cyberinfrastructure and Engineer and Educator (CI2E) position at the University of Cincinnati (UC) made strides in developing and engaging the university and the broader, regional research community. He established himself as the NSF XSEDE campus champion, helping students and faculty with their account registration and management and facilitated the XSEDE monthly HPC workshops from August ? December 2018. He acted in a leadership role by creating and charging the UC Research Technical Advisory Group (R-TAG), a sub-committee of the UC IT Governance Research & Development committee, which met monthly. This group brought together technical research computing staff who represented various disciplines across the University to discuss the high-speed research network, UCScienceNet (UCSN), progress, problems and solutions.  They compared data transfer results and shared best data practices. The development of such an overlooked and specialized community within UC helped bridge research ?silos? and served as a sort of research and computing ?needs-analysis? assessment. This group will now participate in the UC Advanced Research Computing Consortium helping their research faculty to schedule and utilize the new HPC campus-cluster.  Further multi-disciplinary outreach activities took place at the biannual new faculty orientations, UC Data Day Symposium 2017 and 2018 and the Undergraduate Research Expo, where the CI2E met with all the incoming faculty, symposia attendees and students to discuss their research and help them get connected to the UCSN. During his tenure, he served as the Ohio Supercomputer Center (OSC) liaison for UC and helped facilitate OSC workshops on campus. He helped faculty and students set up OSC accounts, provided support for their on-demand interface and significantly, he helped them move data to and from OSC with the UCSN.

Other tangible outcomes include the development of hand-outs, documentation including security guidelines, purchasing guide and FAQs that is available on the UCIT R&D website as well as the UC Office of Research ?Research How2? tool, and a database of UC researchers and (potential) UCSN users. This information has been used to connect researchers for funding opportunities and enhance shared computational resources. The eight UCSN connections across campus served a broad and diverse group of research domains including engineering, medicine, humanities, as well as biological, physical and social sciences and the CI2E worked to remove obstacles-for-use and facilitated and educated on the use and capacity of the UCSN resource. Together, all these activities demonstrate the enabling role of the CI2E?s technical expertise.
